member.name: P:Microsoft.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteBinder.CacheIdentity
member.summary: The key used by the binding rule cache. The expressions returned by the method are cached and shared across dynamic call sites. All call sites with their CacheIdentity equal are considered to be performing identical dynamic operation and therefore the binding expressions for such dynamic operations will be shared by the dynamic runtime.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.DynamicObject
member.summary:
Provides a simple class that can be inherited from to create an object with dynamic behavior at runtime. Subclasses can override the various binder methods (GetMember, SetMember, Call, etc...) to provide custom behavior that will be invoked at runtime.
If a method is not overridden then the DynamicObject does not directly support that behavior and the call site will determine how the binding should be performed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.IDynamicMetaObjectProvider
member.summary: Represents a dynamic object, that can have its operations bound at runtime.
member.remarks: Objects that want to participate in the binding process should implement an IDynamicMetaObjectProvider interface, and implement to return a .

member.summary: Returns the responsible for binding operations performed on this object.
member.param: The expression tree representation of the runtime value.
member.returns: The to bind this object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.IArgumentProvider
member.summary:
Provides an internal interface for accessing the arguments that multiple tree nodes (DynamicExpression, ElementInit, MethodCallExpression, InvocationExpression, NewExpression, and InexExpression).
This enables two optimizations which reduce the size of the trees. The first is it enables the nodes to hold onto an IList of T instead of a ReadOnlyCollection. This saves the cost of allocating the ReadOnlyCollection for each node. The second is that it enables specialized subclasses to be created which hold onto a specific number of arguments. For example Block2, Block3, Block4. These nodes can therefore avoid allocating both a ReadOnlyCollection and an array for storing their elements saving 32 bytes per node.
Meanwhile the nodes can continue to expose the original LINQ properties of ReadOnlyCollections. They do this by re-using 1 field for storing both the array or an element that would normally be stored in the array.
For the array case the collection is typed to IList of T instead of ReadOnlyCollection of T. When the node is initially constructed it is an array. When the compiler accesses the members it uses this interface. If a user accesses the members the array is promoted to a ReadOnlyCollection.
For the object case we store the 1st argument in a field typed to object and when the node is initially constructed this holds directly onto the Expression. When the compiler accesses the members it again uses this interface and the accessor for the 1st argument uses Expression.ReturnObject to return the object which handles the Expression or ReadOnlyCollection case. When the user accesses the ReadOnlyCollection then the object field is updated to hold directly onto the ReadOnlyCollection.
It is important that the Expressions consistently return the same ReadOnlyCollection otherwise the re-writer will be broken and it would be a breaking change from LINQ v1. The problem is that currently users can rely on object identity to tell if the node has changed. Storing the ROC in an overloaded field enables us to both reduce memory usage as well as maintain compatibility and an easy to use external API.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.ListArgumentProvider
member.summary: Provides a wrapper around an IArgumentProvider which exposes the argument providers members out as an IList of Expression. This is used to avoid allocating an array which needs to be stored inside of a ReadOnlyCollection. Instead this type has the same amount of overhead as an array without duplicating the storage of the elements. This ensures that internally we can avoid creating and copying arrays while users of the Expression trees also don't pay a size penalty for this internal optimization. See IArgumentProvider for more general information on the Expression tree optimizations being used here.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.ArgumentPrepender
member.summary:
Prepends an argument and stands in as an IArgumentProvider. Avoids creation of a ReadOnlyCollection or making a temporary array copy.
Note this is always as better than allocating an array because an empty array has 16 bytes of overhead - and so does this.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression.ReturnReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0}@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is called from various methods where we internally hold onto an IList of T or a ROC of T. We check to see if we've already returned a ROC of T and if so simply return the other one. Otherwise we do a thread-safe replacement of hte list w/ a ROC which wraps it.
Ultimately this saves us from having to allocate a ReadOnlyCollection for our data types because the compiler is capable of going directly to the IList of T.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression.ReturnReadOnly(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.IArgumentProvider,System.Object@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is similar to the ReturnReadOnly of T. This version supports nodes which hold onto multiple Expressions where one is typed to object. That object field holds either an expression or a ReadOnlyCollection of Expressions. When it holds a ReadOnlyCollection the IList which backs it is a ListArgumentProvider which uses the Expression which implements IArgumentProvider to get 2nd and additional values. The ListArgumentProvider continues to hold onto the 1st expression.
This enables users to get the ReadOnlyCollection w/o it consuming more memory than if it was just an array. Meanwhile The DLR internally avoids accessing which would force the ROC to be created resulting in a typical memory savings.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression.ReturnObject``1(System.Object)
member.summary:
Helper which is used for specialized subtypes which use ReturnReadOnly(ref object, ...). This is the reverse version of ReturnReadOnly which takes an IArgumentProvider.
This is used to return the 1st argument. The 1st argument is typed as object and either contains a ReadOnlyCollection or the Expression. We check for the Expression and if it's present we return that, otherwise we return the 1st element of the ReadOnlyCollection.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.AutoRuleTemplate
member.summary:
Handles auto-templating of rules. There are three important actions this performs: 1. Detects if templating is possible between two rules 2. Re-writes a non-templated rule into templated form 3. Extracts the constants from a non-templated rule which is compatible with a templated rule so that they can be used by the existing generated code.
Auto-templating is currently only used for serially monomorphic call sites where we can easily avoid code gen. It is not used for polymorphic call sites although such a feature could be enabled in the future.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.AutoRuleTemplate.CopyOrCreateTemplatedRule``1(Microsoft.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteRule{``0},Microsoft.Runtime.CompilerServices.CallSiteRule{``0})
member.summary: The entry point into auto-rule tempating. This consumes the monomorphic rule which is currently stored in the cache as well as the rule that was just produced by the binder.
member.param: The original rule that is currently stored in the cache. This rule may or may not be a templated rule.
The new rule produced by a binder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.BlockExpression.Rewrite(System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.ParameterExpression},Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression[])
member.summary:
Makes a copy of this node replacing the parameters/args with the provided values. The shape of the parameters/args needs to match the shape of the current block - in other words there should be the same # of parameters and args.
parameters can be null in which case the existing parameters are used.
This helper is provided to allow re-writing of nodes to not depend on the specific optimized subclass of BlockExpression which is being used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.BlockExpression.ReturnReadOnlyExpressions(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.BlockExpression,System.Object@)
member.summary:
Helper used for ensuring we only return 1 instance of a ReadOnlyCollection of T.
This is similar to the ReturnReadOnly which only takes a single argument. This version supports nodes which hold onto 5 Expressions and puts all of the arguments into the ReadOnlyCollection.
Ultimately this means if we create the ROC we will be slightly more wasteful as we'll have a ROC + some fields in the type. The DLR internally avoids accessing anything which would force the ROC to be created.
This is used by BlockExpression5 and MethodCallExpression5.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.BlockExpressionList
member.summary: Provides a wrapper around an IArgumentProvider which exposes the argument providers members out as an IList of Expression. This is used to avoid allocating an array which needs to be stored inside of a ReadOnlyCollection. Instead this type has the same amount of overhead as an array without duplicating the storage of the elements. This ensures that internally we can avoid creating and copying arrays while users of the Expression trees also don't pay a size penalty for this internal optimization. See IArgumentProvider for more general information on the Expression tree optimizations being used here.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.TryExpression
member.summary:
Represents a try/catch/finally/fault block.
The body is protected by the try block. The handlers consist of a set of s that can either be catch or filters. The fault runs if an exception is thrown. The finally runs regardless of how control exits the body. Only one of fault or finally can be supplied. The return type of the try block must match the return type of any associated catch statements.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.CompilerScope
member.summary:
CompilerScope is the data structure which the Compiler keeps information related to compiling scopes. It stores the following information: 1. Parent relationship (for resolving variables) 2. Information about hoisted variables 3. Information for resolving closures
Instances are produced by VariableBinder, which does a tree walk looking for scope nodes: LambdaExpression and BlockExpression.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.CompilerScope._parent
member.summary: parent scope, if any

member.summary: The expression node for this scope Can be LambdaExpression, BlockExpression, or CatchBlock

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.CompilerScope.IsMethod
member.summary: True if this node corresponds to an IL method. Can only be true if the Node is a LambdaExpression. But inlined lambdas will have it set to false.

member.summary: Variables defined in this scope, and whether they're hoisted or not Populated by VariableBinder

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.CompilerScope.ReferenceCount

member.summary:
Scopes whose variables were merged into this one
Created lazily as we create hundreds of compiler scopes w/o merging scopes when compiling rules.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.LambdaCompiler
member.summary: Dynamic Language Runtime Compiler. This part compiles lambdas.

Mutates the MethodBuilder parameter, filling in IL, parameters, and return type.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.LambdaCompiler.GetLambdaArgument(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the argument slot corresponding to the parameter at the given index. Assumes that the method takes a certain number of prefix arguments, followed by the real parameters stored in Parameters

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.LambdaCompiler.EmitLambdaArgument(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the index-th argument. This method provides access to the actual arguments defined on the lambda itself, and excludes the possible 0-th closure argument.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.LambdaCompiler.CreateLazyInitializedField``1(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an unitialized field suitible for private implementation details Works with DynamicMethods or TypeBuilders.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Set`1
member.summary: A simple hashset, built on Dictionary{K, V}

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller
member.summary: Expression rewriting to spill the CLR stack into temporary variables in order to guarantee some properties of code generation, for example that we always enter try block on empty stack.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.RewriteExpression(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression,Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.Stack)
member.summary: Rewrite the expression
member.param: Expression to rewrite
State of the stack before the expression is emitted.
member.returns: Rewritten expression.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.ToTemp(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression,Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression@)
member.summary: Will perform: save: temp = expression return value: temp

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.MakeBlock(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression[])
member.summary: Creates a special block that is marked as not allowing jumps in. This should not be used for rewriting BlockExpression itself, or anything else that supports jumping.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.MakeBlock(System.Collections.Generic.IList{Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression})
member.summary: Creates a special block that is marked as not allowing jumps in. This should not be used for rewriting BlockExpression itself, or anything else that supports jumping.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller._tm
member.summary: The source of temporary variables

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller._startingStack
member.summary: Initial stack state. Normally empty, but when inlining the lambda we might have a non-empty starting stack state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller._lambdaRewrite
member.summary: Lambda rewrite result. We need this for inlined lambdas to figure out whether we need to guarentee it an empty stack.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.AnalyzeLambda(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.LambdaExpression)
member.summary: Analyzes a lambda, producing a new one that has correct invariants for codegen. In particular, it spills the IL stack to temps in places where it's invalid to have a non-empty stack (for example, entering a try statement).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.Clone``1(System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{``0},System.Int32)
member.summary: Will clone an IList into an array of the same size, and copy all vaues up to (and NOT including) the max index
member.returns: The cloned array.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.RequireNoRefArgs(System.Reflection.MethodBase)
member.summary:
If we are spilling, requires that there are no byref arguments to the method call.
Used for: NewExpression, MethodCallExpression, InvocationExpression, DynamicExpression, UnaryExpression, BinaryExpression.
member.remarks: We could support this if spilling happened later in the compiler. Other expressions that can emit calls with arguments (such as ListInitExpression and IndexExpression) don't allow byref arguments.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.RequireNotRefInstance(Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Expression)
member.summary:
Requires that the instance is not a value type (primitive types are okay because they're immutable).
Used for: MethodCallExpression, MemberExpression (for properties), IndexExpression, ListInitExpression, MemberInitExpression, assign to MemberExpression, assign to IndexExpression.
member.remarks: We could support this if spilling happened later in the compiler.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._temp
member.summary: Current temporary variable

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._freeTemps
member.summary: List of free temporary variables. These can be recycled for new temps.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._usedTemps
member.summary: Stack of currently active temporary variables.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.TempMaker._temps
member.summary: List of all temps created by stackspiller for this rule/lambda

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.StackSpiller.ChildRewriter
member.summary:
Rewrites child expressions, spilling them into temps if needed. The stack starts in the inital state, and after the first subexpression is added it is change to non-empty. This behavior can be overridden by setting the stack manually between adds.
When all children have been added, the caller should rewrite the node if Rewrite is true. Then, it should call Finish with etiher the orignal expression or the rewritten expression. Finish will call Expression.Comma if necessary and return a new Result.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.SpilledExpressionBlock
member.summary: A special subtype of BlockExpression that indicates to the compiler that this block is a spilled expression and should not allow jumps in.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Linq.Expressions.Compiler.VariableBinder
member.summary: Determines if variables are closed over in nested lambdas and need to be hoisted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CacheDict`2
member.summary:
Provides a dictionary-like object used for caches which holds onto a maximum number of elements specified at construction time.
This class is not thread safe.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CacheDict`2.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a dictionary-like object used for caches.
member.param: The maximum number of elements to store.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CacheDict`2.TryGetValue(`0,`1@)
member.summary: Tries to get the value associated with 'key', returning true if it's found and false if it's not present.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CacheDict`2.Add(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds a new element to the cache, replacing and moving it to the front if the element is already present.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CacheDict`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Returns the value associated with the given key, or throws KeyNotFoundException if the key is not present.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.CollectionExtensions.ToReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary:
Wraps the provided enumerable into a ReadOnlyCollection{T}
Copies all of the data into a new array, so the data can't be changed after creation. The exception is if the enumerable is already a ReadOnlyCollection{T}, in which case we just return it.

member.summary: Requires the range [offset, offset + count] to be a subset of [0, array.Count].
member.exception: Array is null.
Offset or count are out of range.

member.summary: Requires the array and all its items to be non-null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.TypeExtensions.MatchesArgumentTypes(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.Type[])
member.summary:
Returns true if the method's parameter types are reference assignable from the argument types, otherwise false.
An example that can make the method return false is that typeof(double).GetMethod("op_Equality", ..., new[] { typeof(double), typeof(int) }) returns a method with two double parameters, which doesn't match the provided argument types.
